metadata.title: Bacterial Nano‐Cellulose Triboelectric Nanogenerator

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Nano Energy
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/nanoen
Full paper
Bacterial Nano‐Cellulose Triboelectric Nanogenerator Hyun-Jun Kima, Eun-Chae Yimb, Jong-Hun Kimc, Seong-Jun Kimb, Jeong-Young Parkc, IlKwon Oha,⁎
a Creative Research Initiative Center for Functionally Antagonistic Nano-Engineering, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 291 Daehak-ro, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 34141, Republic of Korea b Department of Environmental Engineering, Chonnam National University, 77 Yongbong-ro, Buk-gu, Gwangju 61186, Republic of Korea c Graduate School of EEWS, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, 291 Daehak-ro, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 34141, Republic of Korea
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Energy harvesting Triboelectric nanogenerator Self-power Biomaterial Bacterial nanocellulose
A B S T R A C T
Motivated by a desire to resolve the needs of sustainable energy resources, remote sensing electronics, wireless autonomous devices, mobile internet of things (IoT) and portable self-power generators, triboelectric nanogenerators have recently been suggested. However, more specialized target applications to biomedical and wearable devices will require biocompatible and eco-friendly triboelectric materials in power generators. Herein, we report for the first time a bio-triboelectric nanogenerator based on an eco-friendly and naturally abundant biomaterial, bacterial nanocellulose. Initially, bacterial cellulose pellicles were produced in a gel state by Acetobacter xylinum KJ1 in the Glu-Fruc medium and then a bacterial nanocellulose film having transparent and flexible functionalities was regenerated on a current collector via a solubilization process. The bacterial nanocellulose triboelectric nanogenerator was investigated with various input conditions and structural aspects. The working mechanism was also considered by measuring the contact angle and the surface potential of the friction materials. We believe that this study provides new insights to advancing the biocompatible and ecofriendly triboelectric power generator and optimization strategies to achieve high performance of triboelectric nanogenerators.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With advances in electronics technology, as the size of electronic equipment is becoming much smaller, the amount of energy needed to operate electronic devices is getting smaller and smaller. As a result, interest in small-sized energy sources has been growing over the past two decades [1,2]. Internet of things (IoT) and ubiquitous technologies, stemming from a convergence of information technology, environmental technology, and biotechnology based on nanotechnology are emerging at the present time [3]. However, the continuous miniaturization of electronics accomplished by depending entirely on general battery technology can cause specific problems when the energy supply is bulky in size [4]. To resolve the power problems of miniaturized electronics, energy harvesting, which is the process of capturing ambient energy from one or more naturally-occurring energy sources such as light, heat, and mechanical movement, accumulating electricity, and storing that electricity for small and mid-sized devices, has been developed [4,5]. Especially as nanotechnology advances, a minute amount of energy that would otherwise easily get lost can be captured. Recently, Zhong Lin Wang's group developed the triboelectric nano-
generator (TENG), which is a new type of energy harvester based on a conjunction of triboelectrification and electrostatic induction [2]. Also, they have intensively investigated various materials for the friction part, verification mechanism, and diverse generation mode, and have proposed the possibility of triboelectric nanogenerator applications [1,2,6–8]. Even though advances in technology have made living more convenient, there are still some remaining problems that need to be resolved. Especially, waste from electronic devices has become one of the main causes of environmental pollution in many countries [9,10]. Research on biomaterials using environment-friendly, clean, sustainable natural materials is an important area, and related research and development (R &D) has been performed with much attention paid to the importance of new material development to cope with environmental pollution and global warming [11]. To replace organic materials, based on petroleum resources that are being depleted, research trends are particularly focusing on the development of new materials made of abundant natural materials [12]. As a natural polymer, cellulose is an organic compound that is very abundant in nature; indeed, among organic fuels it is second only to coal [13]. Most importantly, the discovery of cellulose produced by bacteria, specifi-
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoen.2017.01.035 Received 17 December 2016; Received in revised form 14 January 2017; Accepted 15 January 2017
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: ikoh@kaist.ac.kr (I.-K. Oh).
Nano Energy 33 (2017) 130–137
Available online 16 January 2017 2211-2855/ © 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
MARK
cally from the Acetobacter xylinum, was attributed to Brown as early as 1886 [14]. After that, much research has been done on bacterial cellulose, its characteristics, and its production for practical use [15,16]. In the view of environmental preservation, bacterial cellulose is well known as an appropriate polymer because it can be fully decomposed by soil microorganisms in a month due to its great biodegradability [17]. Although bacterial cellulose has excellent intrinsic properties such as high elastic modulus, good degree of polymerization, and biocompatibility [15–17], there has so far been no report on the use of bacterial cellulose in a triboelectric nanogenerator until now.
Herein, in this paper, we report for the first time the bacterial nanocellulose bio-triboelectric nanogenerator (BNC Bio-TENG). As a promising eco-friendly green material, the regenerated bacterial nanocellulose film, which was prepared via a solubilization process and has unique functionalities such as transparency, flexibility and biocompatibility, was used as the friction part in the triboelectric nanogenerator. Also, by measuring the contact angle and the surface potential of the friction materials, the working mechanism of the BNC Bio-TENG has been considered. We demonstrate that the fabricated BNC Bio-TENG can generate electrical energy according to surface treatments and has close relationship between electrical output signals and structural aspects such as curvature and friction size.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of regenerated bacterial nanocellulose (BNC)
sections.text: Bacterial cellulose (BC) was basically produced by Acetobacter xylinum KJ1 as BC producer in the Glu-Fruc medium as producer with reference to previous studies [15,18]. After incubating at 30℃ for 36 h, one of the BC pellicles was then statically cultured at 30℃ for 10 days; it was adjusted to pH 5.25. The purified BC was finally obtained from the above BC pellicle after treatment with 0.1 M sodium hydroxide solution at 80 ℃ for 20 min to lyse the bacteria on the BC pellicle, which was then thoroughly washed several times with distilled water until its color changed to white. The purified BC was slowly and fully dried in a vacuum oven at 50 ℃; finally, it was weighed. To make a uniform BNC film, the purified BC should be dissolved at a specific concentration and then dried. Based on the nitration method proposed by Alexander and Mitchell [19], the dried BC was dissolved in ethyl acetate at a concentration of 0.5 w/v% under magnetic stirring for 100 rpm at room temperature. Subsequently, to make a uniform BNC film, ultra-sonication was employed to remove bubbles in homogenous solution; then, the regenerated bacterial nanocellulose (BNC) film was prepared by casting on petri dish in an oven at 40 ℃ as shown in Fig. 1a. For a friction material, the BNC solution was cast on copper foil. (See also Fig. S1 and Fig. S5 in Supporting information).

sections.heading: 2.2. Fabrication of triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG)
sections.text: For the friction parts, the BNC cast on a copper foil and the other copper foil were cut into square pieces with dimensions of 5 cm by 5 cm. The copper foil on the side of BNC was used as the top electrode and was covered with flexible polypropylene (PP) film. The other copper foil, which was covered with a flat polyoxymethylene (POM) plate, played dual roles of bottom electrode and friction part. To fabricate and control the curvature of the arch-shaped nanogenerator, the sides of the PP were prepared so as to be longer than that of the POM; then, the sides of the two covers were taped to each other. For measurement, these two copper foils were connected to each wire.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization
sections.text:
The morphologies of the bacterial cellulose films were investigated using a field emission scanning electron microscope (Nova230, FEI
Company) at a beam landing energy of 3 keV. The changes in the surface chemical bonding of the bacterial cellulose films were characterized by Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR 4100, Jasco). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the bacterial cellulose were measured using a high resolution thin-film X-ray diffractometer (D/ MAX-2500, RIGAKU). The bacterial cellulose films were scanned at 2 θ from 5° to 35°. The contact angles of water droplets on the material surfaces were measured using a contact angle system (Phoenix300, Surface Electro Optics) at room temperature. 10 μL of the deionized water droplets generated by the automatic dispenser of the contact angle system were placed on each friction material. Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) measurements were carried out using an atomic force microscope (Agilent 5500, Agilent Technologies) with a conductive non-contact cantilever coated with Pt/Ir and a nominal resonance frequency of 75 kHz. In order to evaluate the surface potential of the tip, the contact potential difference (CPD) value on a gold plate can be used as the reference value. All TENG measurements were performed under ambient conditions (temperature=20~24℃ and relative humidity=25~40%). For electrical measurements, an oscilloscope (DPO 2002B, Tektronix) with a passive probe (TPP0100, Tektronix) and a data acquisition system (PXI-1042Q and LabVIEW, National Instrument) were used. A repeated press and release process was performed using a function generator (AFG 3022, Tektronix), a power amplifier (BAA 120, TIRA GmbH), and a vibration exciter (S51075, TIRA GmbH). UV–vis spectrometer (V-570, Jasco) was employed to record the optical transmittance of BC before solubilization and BNC after solubilization over the wavelength of 200–800 nm, as shown in Fig. S4.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text: Initially, the BC pellicle produced by bacteria is in a gel-state, with the remaining BC producer and production medium; its size depends mainly on the shape of the incubator [20]. So, in order to fabricate a uniform BNC film with no other components, the BC pellicle should be treated by solubilization at a specific concentration [21]. As can be seen in Fig. 1a, the solubilization step should be proceeded to make the BNC film not only uniform but also flexible and transparent, which gives it much more potential for future transparent devices. The structure and working mechanism of the BNC Bio-TENG are schematically shown in Fig. 1b. BNC and Cu foil were used as friction parts on the upper and lower layers. The layer of Cu foil on the upper side is just a current collector, whereas the layer on the lower side plays dual roles of current collector and friction part. To prevent electrical shorting and to protect the TENG from the external environment, cover layers were attached on the outside of each of the current collectors. The length of the upper cover was slightly longer than that of the lower cover; this curvature of the upper sides was fabricated intentionally. As a result, after two friction films are brought into contact and rub together by compressive force, the TENG will be able to return to its initial shape due to the presence of an elastic and flexible film (see also Fig. S2, Supporting information) [7,22]. It is generally known that the working principle of a TENG is based on coupling effects including triboelectrification and electrostatic induction [23,24]. Under a pressing force, the two friction surfaces can come into physical contact with each other, resulting in oppositely charged surfaces that can compensate for the difference of the physical properties, such as the surface energy, between the surfaces [25,26]. When the two friction surfaces are subsequently separated upon release, an electric potential difference is created between the two electrodes [27]. Then, there is electron flow through the external circuit until the accumulated charges reach an equilibrium state. Subsequently, when the TENG is pressed again to come into contact with the two friction surfaces, an electric potential difference is created with reversed polarity [23,27], resulting in electron flow in a reverse direction.

sections.heading: 3.1. Chemical and surface analyses
sections.text:
The surface chemical bondings of BC structures were characterized by FT-IR to analyze the influence of solubilization. As can be seen in Fig. 2a, characteristic absorption bands assigned to the BC before the
solubilization step were observed at 3400–3200 cm−1 and 1150– 1000 cm−1, which correspond to –OH stretching and C-O-C bending vibration [28,29], respectively. After the BC solubilization, however, the absorption bands of the BNC film located at 1635 cm−1, 1271 cm−1, 1064 cm−1, and 826 cm−1, can be attributed to C˭C vibration, C˭O
vibration, C-O vibration, and C-H stretching, respectively [29–31]. The main differences are that the intensity of the C-O-C peak was reduced markedly, indicating that ether chains between glucose units were destroyed after the solubilization step, and absorption bands including C˭C, C˭O, C-O, and C-H newly appeared.
The BC and BNC structures were further investigated using XRD analysis so as to compare the significant changes in crystalline structure indicated in Fig. 2b. The BC before the solubilization step showed characteristic diffraction peaks at approximately 2θ=14.5° and 16.5°, which were assigned to cellulose Iα, and at 2θ=22.5° corresponding to cellulose Iβ [29,32]. However, the diffraction peaks of the BNC film after the solubilization process were observed at 2θ=12.2° and 18~22°, which were typical for cellulose II [33,34]. XRD patterns of the BNC film were not identical to those of the BC before the solubilization step. Most apparently, the intensity of the diffraction peaks dropped and changed broadly due to the decrease in the cellulose crystallinity through the solubilization step [35]. Also, it is known that the conversion of a single peak to a double peak is characteristic of cellulose regeneration [34]. These results indicate that the transformation from cellulose I to cellulose II occurred after the solubilization step; these results then properly correspond to the results of FT-IR.
As mentioned above, we fabricated the BNC Bio-TENG based on BNC and Cu foils. In addition, the BNC-PI TENG that consisted of BNC and polyimide (PI) was also prepared for the control group. PI has commonly been utilized as a friction material in triboelectric nanogenerator because it is a stable synthetic polymer with thermal stability and excellent mechanical properties. Then, friction materials; BNC, Cu foil, and PI were analyzed by measuring contact angles of water droplets and surface potentials to elucidate the generation mechanism.
First, the water contact angles (θ) of the three-friction materials were measured by the static sessile drop method with a 10 μl water droplet. In a typical solid-liquid-gas system, the contact angle is indirectly used to evaluate adhesiveness. Generally, cases in which the contact angle is lower are taken to indicate higher adhesion [36]. This approach assumes that a lower contact angle correlates to a higher surface energy [49]. In other words, for a water drop placed on a solid surface with high surface energy, the force of attraction between the liquid molecules and the atoms in the solid is stronger than that between the liquid molecules. So, when two dissimilar materials with different levels of surface energy contact each other, possible energy sources such as electron or charged ions/molecules could flow from the high to the low state of the surface energy [25,26,37,49]. As can be seen in Fig. 2c, the measurement results of water contact angles show that the highest contact angle was obtained from BNC, whereas Cu foil gave the lowest contact angle among the three-friction materials. This means that the surface energy of BNC is lower than that of Cu foil. Then, the BNC surface can be negatively charged after contact with the Cu foil, which will be positively charged. Furthermore, the contact angle difference between the BNC and the Cu foil, both of which are materials for the experimental group, is relatively larger than that between the BNC and the PI, which were prepared for the control group. From these results, it can be inferred that triboelectrification will occur much more on the surface of the BNC Bio-TENG.
To determine a possible mechanism of triboelectric generation, the surface potential of the friction materials was also characterized by Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM). Several recent papers have shown that charge transfer between materials with different energy states appears through electron tunneling [26,38]. The KPFM mode, which we employed, was used to map the distribution of the contact potential difference (CPD), which was applied to nullify the potential difference between the Fermi levels of the conductive tip and the sample. Also, the contact potential difference, VCPD, is defined as
V ϕ ϕ
e =
− CPD tip sample
(1)
where ϕtip and ϕsample are the work functions of the tip and the sample,
respectively; e is the electronic charge [39]. According to the working principle of KPFM, when two dissimilar materials come into contact, electrons on the material having higher energy are transferred to the other until the two energy levels are coincident [40,41]. And, it is apparent that each material, either losing or gaining an electron, will be charged into a positive or negative state. Fig. 2d shows the histogram analysis of the CPD for the three-friction materials. As illustrated in Fig. 1b, if the friction materials are in contact with each other, the BNC is charged negatively due to the low energy level of the BNC. Also, the difference of the average CPD values is larger in the materials of the experimental group than in that of the control group; much more triboelectrification can be expected in the BNC Bio-TENG (see the detailed results of Fig. S3 in Supporting information).

sections.heading: 3.2. Electrical output performance
sections.text:
Since mechanical energy, which appears as a kinetic wave energy in actual life, is quite random variable and comes in irregular form, research on the correlation between the outputs of the TENG and the various input conditions is needed [42,43]. In this study, the dynamic input forces applied to the BNC Bio-TENG were generated by a mechanical shaker with various input pulse signals under control of pulse magnitude, frequency, and width considering variable vibration environment. The cathode cables of all measurement devices were connected to the top copper electrode of the BNC film. Then, if electrons flow from the outside to the top electrode, the generated output shows a positive signal. As shown in the schematic illustration of the generation mechanism (Fig. 1b), when two inner surfaces are brought into full contact by the shaker, there will be electron transfer from the material having high surface energy to the material with low surface energy [25,26]. In the case of the BNC Bio-TENG, electrons will be injected from the Cu foil to the BNC, resulting in a negatively charged BNC and a positively charged Cu foil. As the compressive force is releasing, electrons start to flow from the top electrode to the bottom electrode; the measured output shows a negative signal. On the other hand, a positive signal will be generated with reverse electron flow under the pressed state of the TENG. The basic input conditions were set as pulse magnitude of 16.8 N, pulse frequency of 1 Hz, and pulse width of 10 ms. The output voltages of the BNC Bio-TENG and the BNC-PI TENG were measured under the basic input conditions shown in Fig. 3a and b, and were also plotted under different pulse widths from 10 to 500 ms in basic input conditions, as can be seen in Fig. 3c and d, respectively. In comparison with the output voltages of the BNC Bio-TENG and the BNC-PI TENG at the basic input condition, the peak values of the open-circuit voltage for the BNC Bio-TENG and the BNCPI TENG were up to about 13 V and 7 V. As previously mentioned in Fig. 2c and d, the BNC has a large difference of surface characteristics in terms of Cu compared to PI [25]. So, it can be explained that triboelectrification occurs much more on the surface of the BNC BioTENG, resulting in an increase of the output voltage. Next, the output voltages were carefully plotted at variable input pulse widths with a coincidence of time to allow for a positive signal to compare with the negative signal as can be seen in Fig. 3c for the BNC Bio-TENG and Fig. 3d for the BNC-PI TENG. Basically, it is found that each output signal, of either positive or negative voltage, was well generated in accordance with the pulse width of the input signal. Meanwhile, one must be aware that the width of the output signal on each side was generally somewhat narrower in the BNC Bio-TENG than it was in the BNC-PI TENG. Maybe this is due to the surface electrification occurred more rapidly in the conducting material than it did in the insulator material [7,44]; however, further study will be necessary to prove this phenomenon. Next, the electrical output measurement was performed on the BNC Bio-TENG at different magnitude and frequency of the input pulse signal, with results as displayed in Fig. 3e and f, respectively. First, we tested the BNC Bio-TENG at different pulse magnitudes from 16.8 to 51.2 N without any change of the other
conditions, as shown in Fig. 3e. It is well known that higher friction speed can increase the electrification effect, resulting in higher output generation. Owing to the characteristics of the pulse signal, pulse speed is proportional to pulse magnitude; then, the output voltages were found to significantly increase with the pulse magnitude. However, the differential of the output voltage at various pulse magnitudes is larger in the pressing process than in the releasing process, because the BNC Bio-TENG returns to its initial shape indirectly due to structural elasticity rather than due to the action of the mechanical shaker [22]. Second, diverse pulse frequencies from 1 to 10 Hz were applied to the BNC Bio-TENG, and the output voltage remained fairly steady, with only a slight increase, as shown in Fig. 3f. A possible cause for this result is that the charged states on the friction surface are not easily neutralized even under the high frequency of the pulse signal [2], resulting in a large degree of electrostatic induction.
Even though the BNC Bio-TENG can be used as it is, a rectification process, which is a process of transforming the alternating signal into
the direct signal, is needed to utilize the BNC Bio-TENG as a power source in actual life [3,23]. The rectified signal can be stored in energy storage devices, and can then be widely used as needed. Fig. 4a shows that the alternating signal was rectified to a direct signal using a fullwave diode bridge under basic input conditions. Additionally, it is important to confirm the feasibility of the BNC Bio-TENG. Then, the measurements of the accumulative charges and power tests, which can show the applicability of this device for actual applications, were conducted under basic input condition. As can be seen in Fig. 4b, it is expected that the accumulative charge of 8.1 μ C/m2 for only one cycle can be stored in an energy storage device if this rectified signal is intended for energy collection. In practice, it is apparent that the electrical power is related to the load resistance in the system. So, to investigate the effective output power of the BNC Bio-TENG, variable resistances were utilized indirectly as external loads. Fig. 4c indicates that the output peak voltage of the BNC Bio-TENG gradually increases and saturates to the open-circuit voltage with increasing resistance,
whereas the output peak-current follows a reverse trend due to Ohmic loss [7]. Accordingly, under basic input condition, the instantaneous output peak-power ( VW = /Rpeak2 ) [45] is maximized at a load resistance of 1 MΩ, corresponding to a peak-power density of about 4.8 mW/m2 as shown in Fig. 4d.
Furthermore, with a view toward optimization, a further step was taken to investigate the correlation of the output generation with the structural aspects of curvature and friction area. The default setting was that the radius of the curvature and the dimensions of the friction area were 60mm and 5cm × 5cm, respectively. First, the output voltages of the BNC Bio-TENG with different radii of curvature in the upper part were compared, with results as shown in Fig. 5a. Each curvature can have different elastic forces of the curved upper structure, and these forces will be related with how easily the TENG can be deformed and how quickly it can return to its initial state [42]. When the radius of curvature is infinite, which means flat, there will be slight elastic force of the curved part and there will be small gaps between the friction surfaces [2]. So, the electrification will occur to a lesser degree because there is little freedom of movement, resulting in less output voltage generation. In the case of a value of 30mm for the radius of curvature, meanwhile, the upper side can come back to its initial position quickly, as soon as the compressive force is released, resulting in a large degree of the voltage generation. However, in the pressing step, the deformation of the curved upper structure seems to be interrupted by the higher elasticity of BNC-copper composite shell, resulting in smaller output voltage generation in positive mode. Additionally, the absolute peak-voltage ratios of the positive over the negative are compared in Fig. 5b. It can be seen that the absolute peak-voltage ratio was close to 1 when the radius of curvature is 60mm. That is, the amount of electric generation will not fluctuate, but be uniform after the alternating signal is rectified. Then, it is expected that it will be possible to establish a reliable and stable system in the future. Fig. 5c shows that the output
voltage of the BNC Bio-TENG increases with the increased area of the friction surface. Assuming that the pressing plate can sufficiently cover the area of the upper side as shown in Fig. S2, the broader friction surface will receive the transferred charge more and will bring about enhanced electric generation [46]. In order to investigate the effective dimensions of the friction area, the voltage density values, for which peak-voltage was divided by friction area, were considered. As shown in Fig. 5d, then, it appears that a friction area with dimensions of 4cm × 4cm can be effective for the BNC Bio-TENG. In this study, we focused on the development of BNC biomaterial-based TENG and investigated fundamental performances as a power nanogenerator. However, as a further study, practical applications using the BNC BioTENG should be done in near future. Also, the BNC Bio-TENG can be integrated into hybrid energy harvesters [47,48], which simultaneously generate electricity from sunlight, rain drops and wind.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, we have developed a bio-triboelectric nanogenerator (Bio-TENG) based on the eco-friendly and naturally abundant biomaterial, bacterial nanocellulose, having unique functionalities such as transparency, flexibility, and biocompatibility. And the regenerated bacterial nanocellulose (BNC) film used in the triboelectric power generator was prepared via solubilization process from bacterial cellulose produced in a gel state by Acetobacter xylinum KJ1 in the Glu-Fruc medium. The working mechanism for the BNC Bio-TENG was carefully considered by measuring the contact angle and the surface potential of the friction materials. Due to the variability of mechanical energy in actual life, we considered the electrical output performance of the BNC Bio-TENG under various input conditions. With a light touch (input force of 16.8 N), as one case, the accumulative charge and peakpower density of the BNC Bio-TENG can reach ~8.1 μC/m2 and
~4.8 mW/m2, respectively, at a load resistance of 1 MΩ. Furthermore, the relationship between power generation and the structural aspects, including the curvature and the friction area, was investigated in view of optimization. Although there is still much room for improvement in the BNC Bio-TENG, especially in comparison with other synthetic materials and microstructured devices, we believe that this study provides new insight of biomaterials toward advancing the biocompatible and medical bio-triboelectric power generator, environmental dependent power generator, recyclable hybridized power panel, transparent self-power integrated sensing systems, environmental sensing system, and biomedical monitoring system owing to its unique functionalities such as transparency, flexibility, biocompatibility, and biodegradability.

metadata.abstractText: Motivated by a desire to resolve the needs of sustainable energy resources, remote sensing electronics, wireless autonomous devices, mobile internet of things (IoT) and portable self-power generators, triboelectric nanogenerators have recently been suggested. However, more specialized target applications to biomedical and wearable devices will require biocompatible and eco-friendly triboelectric materials in power generators. Herein, we report for the first time a bio-triboelectric nanogenerator based on an eco-friendly and naturally abundant biomaterial, bacterial nanocellulose. Initially, bacterial cellulose pellicles were produced in a gel state by Acetobacter xylinum KJ1 in the Glu-Fruc medium and then a bacterial nanocellulose film having transparent and flexible functionalities was regenerated on a current collector via a solubilization process. The bacterial nanocellulose triboelectric nanogenerator was investigated with various input conditions and structural aspects. The working mechanism was also considered by measuring the contact angle and the surface potential of the friction materials. We believe that this study provides new insights to advancing the biocompatible and ecofriendly triboelectric power generator and optimization strategies to achieve high performance of triboelectric
metadata.creator: Elsevier
